initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
As the situation unfolds, the US government is working to ensure the safety and rights of Sgt Black. The State Department has issued a statement expressing concern over the arrest and is in communication with Russian authorities to gather more information about the charges and the legal process. They are also providing consular assistance to Sgt Black and his family.

The US Army is conducting an investigation into the incident to understand the circumstances leading to Sgt Black's arrest. The military is also reviewing its travel policies and procedures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The arrest of Sgt Black has further strained the already tense relationship between the US and Russia. The US government has condemned Russia's actions and called for the immediate release of Sgt Black and the other Americans being held in Russia.

The situation has also raised concerns among military families and service members about traveling abroad, particularly to countries with strained relations with the US. The Department of Defense has urged service members to comply with travel regulations and to seek official clearance before traveling to high-risk countries.

As the legal process moves forward, the focus remains on ensuring Sgt Black's safety and a fair and transparent legal process. The US government and military will continue to monitor the situation closely and work towards a resolution.

In the meantime, Sgt Black's family has released a statement thanking the US government, the State Department, and the military for their efforts in supporting their loved one. They also expressed their gratitude for the outpouring of support from the public and urged for patience as the legal process unfolds.

The Russian government has yet to respond to the US's calls for the release of Sgt Black and the other Americans being held. Instead, they have released their own statement defending the arrests and accusing the US of interfering in their internal affairs.

The international community has been closely watching the situation, with many countries expressing their concern over the arrest and urging for a resolution. The United Nations has called for a transparent and impartial legal process for Sgt Black and the other detainees.

As the situation continues to develop, both the US and Russian governments have been ramping up their rhetoric. The US has imposed new sanctions on Russia, while Russia has threatened to retaliate. The situation has become a significant point of contention between the two nations, further complicating any potential resolution.

Sgt Black's legal team is working tirelessly to ensure a fair trial and is seeking to have him released on bail. They have expressed their confidence in the Russian legal system and are hopeful for a positive outcome. However, they are also preparing for a lengthy legal battle and are calling for continued support from the US government and the public.

Amidst the escalating tensions, Sgt Black's family remains hopeful for his safe return. In their latest statement, they appealed for peace and diplomacy, urging both governments to prioritize the well-being of the detainees over political posturing. They expressed their appreciation for the efforts of international organizations and the UN, hoping that these entities can mediate a swift and just resolution.

The US government, in response to the Russian statement, has reiterated its calls for the immediate release of Sgt Black and the other detainees. High-level diplomatic meetings between the two nations have been scheduled in an attempt to de-escalate the situation. The outcome of these meetings could significantly impact the legal process and the fate of the detainees.

Meanwhile, Sgt Black's legal team has presented new evidence in support of their client's innocence. This evidence, they claim, will disprove the Russian government's accusations and highlight the political motivations behind the arrest. The team is working closely with the US government and international partners to ensure this evidence is reviewed promptly and thoroughly by the Russian court.

As the world awaits a resolution to this tense standoff, Sgt Black's family, friends, and supporters continue to call for patience, understanding, and solidarity. In the midst of this geopolitical turmoil, Sgt. Black himself has managed to send a letter to his family, assuring them of his well-being and expressing his gratitude for their unwavering support. The Russian government, while maintaining its stance on the detainments, has acknowledged receipt of the new evidence presented by Sgt. Black's legal team. Sgt. Black's family, while relieved to hear from him directly, remains deeply concerned about the ongoing situation.
